title: How to turn protest into powerful change - Eric Liu

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of the three core strategies mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To organize more protests and demonstrations

options.label: B
options.text: To peacefully turn awareness into action and protest into durable political power

options.label: C
options.text: To overthrow existing governments and institutions

options.label: D
options.text: To raise awareness about social and economic issues

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of "expanding the frame of the possible" in the context of civic engagement?

options.label: A
options.text: To limit the scope of possible solutions to a problem

options.label: B
options.text: To push the boundaries of what is considered possible and explore new ideas

options.label: C
options.text: To accept the status quo and work within existing power structures

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on a single, defining issue and ignore other perspectives

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of choosing a "defining fight" in the context of civic engagement?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows individuals to focus on a single issue and ignore other perspectives

options.label: B
options.text: It enables individuals to set the terms of the debate and create a sharp, emblematic contrast

options.label: C
options.text: It requires individuals to compromise and work with existing power structures

options.label: D
options.text: It is a way to avoid conflict and controversy

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of seeking an "early win" in the context of civic engagement?

options.label: A
options.text: To achieve a final, ultimate goal

options.label: B
options.text: To create momentum and change what people think is possible

options.label: C
options.text: To demonstrate the futility of protest and civic engagement

options.label: D
options.text: To focus on a single, defining issue and ignore other perspectives

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the key to achieving lasting positive change through protest and civic engagement?

options.label: A
options.text: A single, sudden triumph

options.label: B
options.text: The long, slow slog of pressuring policymakers, using the media, and persuading skeptical neighbors

options.label: C
options.text: A focus on a single, defining issue and ignoring other perspectives

options.label: D
options.text: Accepting the status quo and working within existing power structures

title: Self-assembly: The power of organizing the unorganized - Skylar Tibbits

multiple-choice.question: What is self-assembly in the context of biology and chemistry?

options.label: A
options.text: A process where ordered parts come together to form a disorganized structure.

options.label: B
options.text: A system where unordered parts come together in an organized structure, completely on their own.

options.label: C
options.text: A method of building complex structures using traditional manufacturing techniques.

options.label: D
options.text: A phenomenon that only occurs in the biological world.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self-assembly in biology?

options.label: A
options.text: The process of cellular division.

options.label: B
options.text: The folding of proteins into 3D structures.

options.label: C
options.text: The replication of DNA.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: How do proteins self-assemble into 3D structures?

options.label: A
options.text: Through the interaction between amino acids along the chain and the relationship between the chain and the environment.

options.label: B
options.text: Through the action of external forces, such as magnets or electricity.

options.label: C
options.text: Through the process of cellular division.

options.label: D
options.text: Through the replication of DNA.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of self-assembly being used as a design and engineering tool?

options.label: A
options.text: The creation of molecular microchips for computers.

options.label: B
options.text: The development of 3D printing technology.

options.label: C
options.text: The design of traditional manufacturing systems.

options.label: D
options.text: The construction of buildings using traditional materials.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential application of self-assembly in the future?

options.label: A
options.text: The creation of materials that can repair themselves.

options.label: B
options.text: The development of water pipes that can reconfigure on demand.

options.label: C
options.text: The design of buildings that can adapt on their own to environmental or dynamic loading.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of having a cognitively diverse team when it comes to generating creative ideas?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to a decrease in the overall number of ideas generated.

options.label: B
options.text: It results in a smaller pool of useful ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a massive uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the number of ideas generated.

multiple-choice.question: Why are people often attracted to others who think like them?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes them feel uncomfortable and challenges their worldview.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes them feel smarter and validates their worldview.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a decrease in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on their feelings or worldview.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with surrounding yourself with like-minded others when working on complex tasks?

options.label: A
options.text: You become more confident about a solution that might be correct.

options.label: B
options.text: You become more confident about a solution that might be gravely mistaken.

options.label: C
options.text: You get a massive uplift in collective intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: You are able to deliver a solution more quickly.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what will be the key feature of competitive advantage for the next 50 years?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive homogeneity

options.label: B
options.text: Cognitive diversity

options.label: C
options.text: Collective intelligence

options.label: D
options.text: Economic forecasting

multiple-choice.question: What is the flaw in the logic of the eminent economic forecaster mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: He believes that working with people who think differently is the key to success.

options.label: B
options.text: He believes that his model is the best one out there.

options.label: C
options.text: He believes that he should be working with people who think like him.

options.label: D
options.text: He fails to recognize the importance of cognitive diversity.
